reviewText: Even doing a comedy, a movie about figure skating would have to have the perfect choreography and glossy scenes.  `Blades of Glory' does just that even as a fun and frolicking movie that both pokes fun and pays homage to a graceful sport.  If not you wouldn't have the ample cameos from Scott Hamilton, Peggy Fleming, Brian Botano, Nancy Kerrigan, et al. who authenticate this loopy glide through skating.  Just like the rest of us, they like to lighten up and have a few laughs.The movie introduces a rivalry between men's figure skating champions Jimmy MacElroy (Jon Heder `Napoleon Dynamite') and Chazz Michael Michaels (Will Farrell).  The two couldn't be more different.  Jimmy is adopted by a wealthy patron who spots him doing a pirouette on the ice of an orphanage headed by a priest.  Dysfunctional, he nevertheless, absorbs all the amenities of a silver spoon lifestyle.  In contrast, Chazz has grown up on "the other side of the tracks".  Brought up bereft, rough in deed and stubble, this tattoo-toting sex-addict hails from Detroit and rises up as a rebel crowd favorite, cheering him on to beat his rich boy rival.  Having to share the limelight at a medal ceremony, both skaters get into a brawl that has them both banned from competition for life.From here they split to separate, humiliating lives:  Chazz is a performer in "Grublets on Ice," an "Ice Follies" family show that's as empty as his whiskey flask after a drinking binge.  Jimmy is reduced to fitting people with skates at a sports' outfitter.  When Jimmy's adoring friend, Hector, pays a visit, they find an escape clause to get out of their life sentence imposed by The National Skating Federation.  When another fight gets both has-been skaters on the news, a replayed videotape gives Jimmy's Coach (Craig T. Nelson, who else?) a brilliant idea.Now both men will have to work together to win a couples' skating championship. But with so much animosity, who will lead and who will follow?  Added to their dilemma, sibling pair prodigies, Stranz and Fairchild Van Waldenburg ('SNL''s Will Arnett and Amy Poehler)," are a nasty nemeses.  Born "out of the wombs and onto the ice" they won't spare their younger sister, Katie (Jenna Fichel, Pam of 'Office' fame) to do their dirty work, scheming and spying on the same gender couple.`Blades of Glory' is good entertainment.  It wins for pace and execution (5.9), is original in style (5.5), and the form of the story is a crowd pleaser (5.4), with enough twists and turns in the development to maintain our interest (5.6), but has some loopy (loop de loop) lines that are familiar for a fun and cheesy franchise (5.2).  Glitzy and funny.
summary: Fun Show Wins for Original Style and Execution, Falters for Familiar Routines

reviewText: Jimmy MacElroy (Jon Heder) and Chazz Michael Michaels (Will Ferrell) are ice skating champions until they tie for first place one day and get into a fight on the podium. They get banned for life from figure skating and wind up doing regular Joe-jobs. Chazz, a self-proclaimed sex-addict, gets gigs as a mascot on ice while Jimmy, the sensitive one, works as a clerk at a skate shop. It's only when one of Jimmy's obsessed fans brings to his attention a loophole; he was banned from single events and there's nothing prohibiting him from skating in pairs. He needs a partner and his old coach (played to perfection by Craig T. Nelson) thinks Chazz and Jimmy would make a great pair. Thus begins the road to the figure skating championship in pairs featuring two men together for the first time.An overall very funny film, more so than I expected. I'm a huge fan of Ferrell, not so much of Heder, but they had good chemistry together and their two different styles complemented each other quite well. Even if a few of the jokes fall flat, most of them are hilarious and the situations they find themselves in are so preposterous that you can't help but laugh. I was also impressed by the actors' skating abilities; they had to skate quite a bit (the acrobatics might have been done by stunt doubles but they still had to skate here and there) and they made it look easy. The supporting cast was comprised of regular Frat Pack members and friends such as Luke Wilson, Jenna Fischer, and Romany Malco. They all brought their funny lines to the part. Real-life skating champions also made their appearances; Brian Boitano, Peggy Fleming, Dorothy Hamill, Nancy Kerrigan all had cameo roles, to name a few. The final part of the film was shot and takes place in my hometown of Montreal so I had a good time recognizing the various locations and venues.Not as funny as other Ferrell classics like Old School, Night at the Roxbury, or Anchorman, but still worth the price of admission. More like "it's so silly it's funny" kind of humor.  Fans of Ferrell and/or Heder shouldn't be disappointed.

reviewText: There are parts of `Blades of Glory' so laugh out loud funny you can pretty much forgive the utter ridiculous tone the film ultimately takes.  I'm a huge Will Ferrell fan.  What can I say but the man makes me laugh all the time, and here is no exception.  Ferrell has a little help though, from newfound funnyman Jon Heder who just seems to be having an incredibly fast-rising career thanks to a little movie called `Napoleon Dynamite'.  Like I said, there are some really funny sequences here, some great one-liners and overall some hilarious parts of the film, and then there are some really overly ridiculous scenes, some stupid one-liners and overall some mind-numbing excuses for comedy.  It's a mixed bag of sorts, but its one bag worth opening.  No, this is not Ferrell's finest moment, and overall this film has nothing on `Talladega Nights' but not every movie can be perfection.Ferrell plays figure skater Chazz Michael Michaels, a professed sex-addict who uses his raw sexuality to connect with the crowd through his routines.  The fact that Ferrell decided to play a sex-god is hilarious in itself.  His prime opponent is Jimmy MacElroy, played by Jon Heder.  MacElroy was adopted at a young age by a wealthy man obsessed with winners who pampered Jimmy while training him to become perfect on the ice.  After a tie delivers the gold medal to both Chazz and Jimmy their rivalry explodes in a humiliating act of aggression that results in a mascot ignited in flames and leaves both Michaels and MacElroy banned from the world of male figure skating permanently.  All seems lost.  Michaels is reduced to the villain in a cheap icecapades production and Jimmy finds himself disowned by his adopted father and left to fend for himself working in a skate-shop.  Then they are presented with a proposition.  They may not be able to skate separately but there is nothing preventing them from skating together.The pairing of two male skaters, enemy's at that, is enough to start a media frenzy, but it also results in some heated competition with their rival skating team, brother and sister pair Stranz and Fairchild, played by the hilarious Amy Poehler and Will Arnett.  Between the boys training and the on-ice antics of the two pairs, `Blades of Glory' delivers the goods, or at least enough of them to satisfy the viewer.  There are a few let downs, one of them being Craig T. Nelson's character and performance, both of which come off forced, especially when he's given one-liners that are as painful to listen to as they must have been for Nelson to speak.  One supporting player that was such a joy to watch was Nich Swardson who plays Jimmy's stalker.  He's just hilarious throughout the film and makes up for the bore that is Nelson.The routines are funny in their own right if not a little too predictable (I mean there are only so many things two men can do together to come off perverted, and they chose to cover all those bases) but what really makes for a good laugh is the dialog that runs between Ferrell and Heder.  They both are so quick witted, but surprisingly it's Heder that one-ups his co-star here.  As Jimmy Heder is pure comedic perfection, fully grasping his characters queer sense of innocence.  He just had me rolling in just about every frame.  There is also a little videotape of the mythical iron-lotus that will either have you gagging or laughing...I was laughing, hard.  So, there is enough here to really enjoy, despite the fact that it's not as good as it could have been.  Ferrell is funny, Heder is hilarious and overall `Blades of Glory' is worth the price of admission.
summary: Short of comedic perfection but still worth a belly laugh...

reviewText: There are so many reasons why BLADES OF GLORY should not be a good movie. First, Will Ferrell is twice as old and twice as big as any successful male figure skater. Second, John Heder hasn't exactly been lighting up the screen since Napolean Dynamite. Third, all of the characters are charicitures, over the top, lampoons, spoofs, etc. There isn't a serious character to ground the movie in reality. In spite of all going against it, BLADES OF GLORY is an hilarious comedy and one of Ferrell's best.Ferrell is Chazz Michael Michaels, skating's bad boy and a raunchy, selfish sex addict. Heder is Jimmy MacElroy, a skating prodigy raised since he was a toddler to win the gold. After a fight on the medal stand, both are banned for life from skating. Three years later, Michaels is reduced to the lead in an Ice-Capades knock off. MacElroy is now working in a sporting goods store. They learn of a loophole in the rules: They can skate together in the couples category. Michaels' old coach, played by Craig T Nelson, tries to form the duo into a top notch pair, and has only a month to do it. Michaels is full of attitude, MacElroy is uptight, and neither want to touch the other. Yet through several hilarious scenes full of slapstick and verbal sparring, the two learn to skate together. The best part of the film for me is when the Coach is trying to teach the pair of move called the Iron Lotus. He shows them a video of the only time it was tried before, in North Korea. That is AWESOME!Michaels and MacElroy qualify for the "Olympics" and face off against American brother/sister combo Fairchild and Stranz Van Waldenberg. These two are crazy, and will do anything to win, including forcing sister Katy (Jenna Fisher) to spy on Michaels and MacElroy.Fans of Ferrell should love this movie. While Ferrell is the star, Heder more than holds is own and is just as funny. Amy Poehler and Will Arnett are hilarious as well as the Van Waldenbergs. I was pleasantly surprised at how good this movie was. The skating routines were great and the characters were funny. This is a must buy if you like these kinds of movies.
summary: Ferrell and Heder shine as a figure skating tandem. Hilarious movie!

reviewText: I also find Will Ferrell a bit hit or miss.  When he's on, he's on and when he's off it can be painful to watch.  With this movie, though, he really hit the mark.  It's chock full of silliness and sight gags that make watching it a lot of fun. The character in this movie is more or less interchangeable with most Ferrell characters but that's not the point.  The point is the sheer silliness of the plot, the over the top events, and the hilarity of watching skating star after skating star make often surprising cameo appearances.Jon Heder is really wonderful in this movie.  Where Ferrell is pure silliness, Heder is good at creating some nuance in his characters.  Though his characters tend to be spacey and weird, he does a good job of making them somewhat real.  He has a good sense for when understatement can do a great deal more than something very overt and obvious.  I think he is a great talent and look forward to seeing more of him.As far as slapstick comedies go, this one is something of a gem and is worth watching solely for the hilariously silly skating routine at the end of the movie.  Ferrell and Heder make a great duo and I'd like to see them do another movie together.

reviewText: This movie is without a doubt a Will Ferrell vehicle, but for the most part it's funny all the same."Blades of Glory" is a movie about 2 rival figure skaters, Chazz Michael Michaels (played by Will Ferrell), and Jimmy MacElroy (played by Jon Heder), who are simultaniously given a life ban on their sport after getting into a fist fight with each other when they tie for a gold medal at a national competition. Three years later, Chazz and Jimmy discover a loophole in the rulebook that says they are only banned from competing in their previous division (single men's skating), but that they could compete in a different division, like pair skating. Grudgingly, they come together and decide to compete as the first ever male pair skaters -- but these old enemies are more than reluctant to cooperate with each other. Throw in a new (and ruthless) rival pair skating duo (played by the hilarious Amy Poehler and Will Arnett), and you've got yourself a movie!This type of story and character lends itself very well to Will Ferrell's style of improv comedy. About 80% of Ferrell's lines were either improvised by him, or slightly altered from the original dialogue. That takes amazing talent, which Ferrell possesses in abundance, but at times the plot grates a little. It's highly predictable, which makes it no less entertaining -- it just means there aren't many surprises.Sadly, the comedic talent of Jon Heder is largley eclipsed by Ferrell's shining star (and over the top performance). After debuting to thunderous acclaim inNapoleon Dynamite, Jon Heder has had a bit of difficulty living up to his initial success (although I suppose starring alongside Will Ferrell in a top grossing comedy is considered pretty successful).Like most sports movies, body doubles during the more difficult skating sequences are fairly obvious, but to their credit both stars manage to skate while not appearing like they are constantly in jeopardy of falling on their respective behinds (both Heder and Ferrell trained extensively with Michelle Kwan's coach, Sarah Kawahara), even though Heder actually broke his ankle during training.Bottom line, if you go into it expecting to see a typical Ferrell comedy...you will be exactly right. This is par for the course for him, but it's still got quite a few funny moments!
summary: Comedy on Ice -- a Will Ferrell vehicle, but pretty entertaining.

reviewText: Jimmy MacElroy and Chazz Michael Michaels are long-time figure skating rivals. They are complete opposites - Jimmy was adopted by a man who trained him from a young age to be a champion and is germophobic; Chazz is a boozing sex addict. It pokes fun at both skating (the costumes, music, routines) and its fans (who act more like they are at a football game instead of a skating competition), but it's not all that edgy. In fact, while Jon Heder at times plays Jimmy as being a bit effeminate, the movie skates around the issue of homosexuality in figure skating by making Chazz a sex addict usually surrounded by several women and giving Jimmy a female love interest. None of the movie is meant to be taken seriously and figure skating purists should ignore everything the movie gets wrong about figure skating (perhaps intentionally). None of the actors are going for Academy awards in this movie and much of the acting (and action) is over the top, but all of the actors seem to be having fun, especially Will Ferrell, Jon Heder, Will Arnett and Amy Poehler. reviewText: It's been a while since I dug figure skating, way back in the '90s. Admittedly and a tad shamefacedly, my temporary fascination with this sport stemmed mostly from the infamous Nancy Kerrigan/Tonya Harding incident. But, nowadays, no, I'm not feeling love for figure skating. And BLADES OF GLORY, as uproarious and ribald as it is, doesn't at all tempt me into coming back into the fold. First and foremost, this flick is a farce; it pokes fun at the conventions of figure skating: the costumes, the music, the routines, the atmosphere of propriety, the adoring fans...The dubious routines witnessed here seem ideal for exhibitions but, in competitive events, most likely wouldn't draw appreciative points from the universally uptight and begrudging judges (they like things done just so, though the Iron Lotus maneuver in this movie might impress a 6.0 score out of 'em). Ferrell's character, in particular, with his lack of finesse and his unclassical sensibilities, wouldn't fare too well in real life.But, make no mistake, BLADES OF GLORY is very, very funny. However, as a guy in the theater audience and as I was laughing my fool head off, I do own up to cringing to certain of the more uncomfortable scenes in the movie (one guy crotch lifting another guy is...well, my buddies and I were definitely not making eye contact, although, peripherally, I did notice soda squirting out of a pal's nostrils). For a film about a sport entrenched in elegant, high-falutin' trappings, the humor here is decidedly crude and low brow. But, then again, this is a Will Ferrell feature film, and Ferrell seems to revel in that sort of muck. And good for him, I say. He makes me laugh, the doughy dude.[...]Will Ferrell once again howlingly rises to the occasion with his depiction of the obtuse but very confident Chazz Michael Michaels. Ferrell handily owns every scene he's in and garners the most laughs. Off the top of my head, Ferrell and Jack Black have got to be the top two actors most comfortable in parading their very tone-challenged bodies. Jon Heder plays second banana *sorry* to decent effect; honestly, though, he's a little too passive in this part. He makes up for that with some good moments (that bathroom scene and how he got that key? - wow, that's some gross stuff), but he falls short of being as funny as Ferrell. Given, his wimpy, effeminate character doesn't tickle a man's funny bone as riotously. The real life husband and wife team of Will Arnett and Amy Poehler (of SNL fame) light up the screen as the slightly off Van Waldenbergs. The fifth relevant character is Katie, the overlooked and much crapped on sister of the famous Van Waldenbergs, as sweetly played by Jenna Fischer, who, I'm certain, is a better kisser than displayed here.Cameos by several recognizable names in the figuring skating biz lend some credibility to the film: Nancy Kerrigan, Dorothy Hamill, Peggy Fleming, Sasha Cohen (who's apparently a groupie of Chazz's). Of this group of actual figure skaters, the most screen time goes to Scott Hamilton, who cheerfully provides broadcasting services here as himself. He shares commentary duties with Jim Lampley (normally an HBO boxing talking head), who, for some reason, looks ill at ease.Believe it or not, there are segments in the film which suffer from too much syrup. When Chazz and Jimmy finally do meet on common ground and become pals, their loyalty and declarations of friendship seem like overkill. I liked it better when things were delightfully acerbic between the two. The best parts of BLADES OF GLORY definitely are the sequences on ice. When not being susceptible to gay panic attacks, I couldn't catch my breath from laughing so hard at all the routines (even the ones by the wicked Waldenbergs). Nick Swardson, by the way, scores in the bit part of Jimmy's stalker. Two favorite scenes of mine: a hilarious chase sequence with both the pursued and pursuer shod in ice skates while traversing very un-icy surfaces. There's also one skating act which shocked me even as it convulsed me further into stitches - those poor, poor North Koreans.

reviewText: Chazz Michael Michaels (Will Farrell) and Jimmy MacElroy (Jon Heder) are the two best figure skaters in the world.  The former has been described as a leather-clad lothario and sex tornado; the latter a quintessential effeminate figure skating prodigy with questionable sexual orientation.  After objectionable scoring (what's new in figure skating?) leads to a gold medal tie, the two can't stand each other enough to share the first-place podium, leading to a sissy fight and a mascot set on fire.  The resulting aftermath at the National Skating Federation leaves both skaters banned for life.  Oh, the unpredictable dramedy. Meanwhile, Heder unsuccessfully tries to dig out the typecast hole created byNapoleon Dynamitewhile woefully serving as the more feminine of the pair and making every possible viewer with Moira Kelly had signed on for the parody.  It's actually pretty hilarious how similar the two movies are.  Untrusting teammates built trust, learn to love the ice again, fight through a tumultuous love triangle, struggle against all odds towards success, and even a ridiculously impossible move - a technique first questioned and later embraced as the saving grace - called the Iron Lotus.Only in a Will Ferrell parody of ice skating can there be ridiculousness to the level that a figure skater wins an adult film award and comedy can come from a male-male figure skating team, however predictable it may be in its uniqueness.  That's where the positives for this movie end and the similarities to The Cutting Edge end.To start with, Heder can't act. This kind of embarrassment did not go well for the International Skating Union either. The organization decides to permanently ban both skaters from single competition and strip of their gold medals. They are devastated by this harsh decision--even Jimmy gets kicked out of his house.3  years have passed. Our rejects are still in the skating business, but not really competing. Jimmy works as a clerk selling skating gear and Chazz works as a skating mascot/performer in a circus--also loves getting drunk between his breaks. What can possibly put these guys back on the right track? Suddenly, a long time Jimmy's fan shows up at the store where he works and tells him that there is a loophole that will allow him to compete once again. Pair skating is something he can legally do. Excited about the news, he talks to his former coach, but he turns him down. Jimmy decides to look for a partner anyways, and he ends up in the ice show where Chazz works. They see each other for the first time in years and fight some more--televised once again. The old coach watches them on TV, but this time, he sees a potential in the way they are fighting--which magically resembles figure skating moves. Now there is an opportunity for redemption. The coach talks to Jimmy and Chazz about getting together to compete for pair skating at the Olympics and to put their differences aside. They agree but it won't be easy. They will have to work harder than never before, and beat the evil pair champions Fairchild Van Waldenberg (Amy Poehler) and her brother Stranz (Will Arnett).Review:Although the "underdog" Hollywood stories are a bit played out nowadays, Blades of Glory overcomes the cliché story by delivering plenty of laughs from start to finish--male figure skating is already something that many men find it amusing, but the filmmakers amplify it in a way that's impossible not to laugh. Do they stereotype people involved in the sport? Absolutely yes, but that's the backbone of this film. It does what Zoolander did for male modeling.Blades of Glory has an excellent cast. Ferrell and Heder are dynamite together. They show lots of charisma and chemistry. Even though, they have different personalities--both very flamboyant, but Chazz being the wild one--some how, they share many things in common. They are like "oil and water" but being together is crucial for success.In the technical department, Blades of Glory gives us plenty of goodies. Not only its length is just right for a comedy--just 93 minutes--we also enjoy the cinematography which is colorful and has that peculiar Olympic touch. Another important aspect of the movie is the special effects used for the skating sequences, which are impossible to recreate in real life, but extremely funny nevertheless--how can you not laugh when two men are skating together as a couple. The final showdown is probably the funniest moments of 2007, when they dance to the classic Flash Gordon main theme by Queen comes out of nowhere. How funny is that?The Verdict:If you are a fan of Will Ferrell's humor, Saturday Night Live, or if you like movies like Zoolander, then by all means, get the DVD and watch Blades of Glory. It delivers the jokes, but also has the underdog fairly tale that won't disappoint. Not recommended for small children.

reviewText: Will Ferrell and Jon Heder combine forces to pull off a very funny comedy about ice skating in "Blades of Glory."  Sure, they essentially play themselves, but they are an excellent duo on the screen.  Ferrell plays Chazz Michael Michaels, a "lone wolf" bad boy who has taken the ice skating world by storm.  Heder is the loveable orphan turned skating phenom, Jimmy McElroy.  After a brief character introduction of Jimmy, the film wastes no time in putting the leads at each other's throats.  After a disastrous event in Stockholm, they are banned from men's skating competition for life by a board that features Dorothy Hamill, Nancy Kerrigan, Brian Boitano and Peggy Fleming.  Three-and-a-half years pass, with both skaters falling on hard times.  Jimmy works in a skate shop and Chazz is boozing it up in a "Grublets on Ice" show.  Thanks to a loophole found by Jimmy's favorite stalker, Hector (Nick Swardson), though, the two reunite as pairs competitors under the tutelage of Jimmy's former coach (played by Craig T. Nelson).What follows is Heder pulling off a hilariously effeminate performance and Ferrell being Ferrell but with some much needed restraint.  Chazz is given all of the best one-liners and oozes sleazeball sexism.  Jimmy is sweet, caring, and totally sheltered.  The film plays off of these polarizing differences to make for a very comedic flick that doesn't run too long nor does it lose it's mood or pacing.  Heck, even Heder's love interest angle with Jenna Fischer doesn't derail the fun as happened with Owen Wilson and Rachel McAdams in "Wedding Crashers."  Throw in a cold adoptive father (the oft-underused William Fichtner) and the devious darlings of pairs skating (played wonderfully by Will Arnett and real-life wife, Amy Poehler) and you have a solid comedy.The DVD is wonderful, packed full of special features including a fun look at psychofan Hector and a very interesting peek at the skating sequences.  The digital transfer is wonderful.  The colors pop off of the screen.Overall, this is a very funny flick that's worthy of multiple viewings.  I highly recommend it.

reviewText: "Blades of Glory" is a comedy that works for a number of reasons, not the least of which being that the subject matter itself is already kind of a joke.  Male figure skaters, with their shiny spandex trousers and fluffy hair-dos, embody a lot of grace, agility, strength, stamina and skill, but they also look pretty silly most of the time, and their "profession" is hard to take seriously.  Or maybe that's just me.It can't just be me, or else this movie would never have been made.  With Will Ferrell playing the nymphomaniacal Chazz Michael Michaels and Jon Heder as the naive prodigy Jimmy MacElroy, the movie is full of opportunities to poke fun at the sport of men frolicking on ice.  As far as that goes, the jokes work pretty well, at least when they're served on the rocks.  Ferrell and Heder both aren't blazing any new trails here (say hello to Ricky Bobby/Ron Burgandy on skates; give a shout out to Napolean Dynamite with better skin and a bit more of a clue), but they are giving us just enough of a spin on their traditional personas to keep things interesting.  They don't have much of a dynamic together, but they do each have their own personal appeal.  When they're spinning and jumping and mugging on their skates, it's hard not to smile at them.  Here are men, making fools of themselves.The rest of the movie isn't quite as graceful, although it's not half bad, either.  A lot of comic talent backs up the action outside of the skating arena -- Will Arnett, Amy Poehler, Jenna Fischer, Craig T. Nelson, Romany Malco, Andy Richter, Rob Corddry, Luke Wilson, and (my personal guilty pleasure) Nick Swardson.  Sometimes the material is a bit flat and weird (like Michaels' visit to a sex-addict workshop or MacElroy's first kiss), but that's probably because the script tends to stray into typical goof-ball comedy nuttiness.  This isn't entirely unexpected.  Most Ferrell comedies tend to ride the same emotional roller coaster with the same peaks and valleys.  I don't even need to go into the storyline (and won't) -- it hardly matters.In spite of the predictability and the (by now) routine gags (Ferrell showing off his oddly lumpy body with pride, Heder playing dumb as if he were actually playing coy), the movie works because of its gaudy flair and almost mindless play for crowd-pleasing silliness.  Much like the male figure skaters that it so aggressively mocks, the movie is slick, audacious, and unapologetically peppy.  It makes good use of the few limited moves possible in the traditional routine, and sometimes it stumbles a bit, but it always recovers in time to spin out that last, great finishing move with an impossibly white smile and a foppish flick of the wrist.

Well, I think this film did a good job bringing this idea to life.  There are also appearance byMy favorite part of the film was the beginning where MacElroy and Chazz Michael Michaels (Will Farrell) compete in the World Championships with documentary ("mockumentary" is probably a better word) footage of their lives shown between the performances.  The mockumentaries were done like the real sports life stories that are broadcast during major sporting events (MacElroy is called "Little Orphan Awesome").  The skating footage is very well-done, especially MacElroy's.  It really looks like the actor is doing those jumps (that "galloping peacock" is hilarious).  The commentators (Scott Hamilton is one) make the scenes even funnier.Having the rivals pair up because they were banned for life from singles competition is a unique twist to the basic good guy/bad guy sports adversaries theme.  The brother/sister pair who try to cheat their way to win (the Van Waldenbergs) and MacElroy falling for their mistreated younger sister aren't the most unique ideas in the world but the "Iron Lotus" move--which is the most dangerous move in figure skating (people lose their heads over it) and the idea of "Coach" (played by "Coach's" Craig T. Nelson) that only two male skaters can pull it off brings another dimension to the competition.The ending was a bit contrived and not as good as the beginning, but on the whole, it is an enjoyable film.  Fans of legitimate figure skating can look out for appearances by Nancy Kerrigan, Scott Hamilton, Brian Boitano, Dorothy Hamill, and Peggy Fleming. The guy who plays MacElroy's stalker, Hector, (Nick Swardson) also plays Terry, the peculiar employee of Tacos, Tacos, Tacos on one of my favorite shows: Reno 911.  He plays the same kind of role here.  There's an extra on this DVD called "Hector: Portrait of a Psychofan."The extras (and there are a lot of them) range from excellent to unwatchable.  "The Making of..." is done tongue-in-cheek and gets very annoying at the end. "Arnett & Poehler: A Family Affair" is just plain stupid.  "Celebrities on Thin Ice," which shows Farrell and Heder practicing was interesting. "20 Questions with Scott Hamilton" is good. The deleted scenes, however, are very worthwhile.  They actually add insight to the characters.  Chazz actually knew Jimmy at the orphanage.  I wonder why some of these scenes were left out.
summary: "Chazz Michaels and Jimmy MacElroy ARE figure skating!"--Chazz Michael Michaels

reviewText: When going in, my expectations were neither high nor low. I guess I figured that, to use Will Ferrell movies as my metrics, it could not possibly be as good as Anchorman but it had to be better than Talladega Nights (Yes, Talladega Nights was THAT bad).Sidenote: It's true. I basically set two extremes and figured it would fall in between. If you didn't happen to catch my common sense approach and think me a genius, you have fantastic taste in geniuses.Jimmy MacElroy (Jon Heder) is the by-the-book, media-darling for the sport of figure skating. Chazz Michael Michaels (Will Ferrell) is the exact opposite, though his bad-boy, sex-object image still allows him to post scores comparable to those of MacElroy. One day they end up in a fight that gets them banned from competition until they come across a loophole. They can compete again, but under the circumstances they must compete in pairs...together. Basically, like Napoleon Dynamite, if you are looking for a plot to this movie you'll never find one. If you want a movie with a decent balance of physical comedy and Will Ferrell making crude jokes, Blades of Glory may surprise you.As long as you take the movie at face value and remember that you are not seeing a movie that is geared towards providing any entertainment other than cheap laughs for dirty jokes, this is a movie you should enjoy. Any time you try to go beyond that and search for something more you will be disappointed.If I may be so bold, it might have been the worst career move ever for Jon Heder to use his own voice in his role as the title character in the love-it-or-hate-it comedy Napoleon Dynamite. The popularity he gained by his part in that movie has given him new opportunities, but they have been small parts because, well, when Jon Heder is in a movie, you have Napoleon Dynamite in that movie. He may continue to fight the up-hill battle of shrugging that stigma, or he can accept his fate. Blades of Glory may have been the first step towards that acceptance. Rather than trying to play support in a cheesy RomCom, he took a "starring" role as the patsy in a slapstick comedy. I can describe his character by saying that he is a tortured soul who was adopted by a billionnaire sports fan who gives him every advantage to succeed in the sport of figure skating, but it is probably easier to put it in terms which are a little easier to understand: In Blades of Glory, Jon Heder is the butt of just about every joke. As that guy, Heder succeeds.I never got hooked on "Arrested Development," but since its demise Will Arnett's name has popped up more and more. I expected that his part in Blades of Glory would be bigger than it was, but it was certainly big enough to see why his popularity is rising.As long as Will Ferrell makes a movie like this every few years, I will forgive him for however many attempts he wants to make to break into "serious" roles. A few of his comedic roles since Anchorman have seemed forced. In Blades of Glory, like in Anchorman, Ferrell seemed really at home in the character. It was a part that just let him do what he does best. Maybe what I am saying is that when Will Ferrell is womanizing, it makes me laugh hysterically.
summary: I am slightly embarrassed at how hard I laughed at this movie.

reviewText: In "Blades of Glory," Will Ferrell and John Heder play two rival figure skaters, Chazz Michael Michaels and Jimmy MacElroy, who are permanently banned from the sport when their gold medal tie results in a fisticuffs melee on the arena ice.  After the men go their separate ways for awhile, Jimmy learns of a loophole in the rules which would allow them to return to skating but only if they compete in the doubles category.  Even though the two men hate each other with the heat of a thousand white-hot suns and they would be the first all-male duo in the history of competitive skating, Chazz and Jimmy agree to set aside their differences and take a stab at mounting a comeback.  The fact that the two of them are complete opposites in terms of demeanor and style - Jimmy is a cupie-faced innocent while Chazz is a swaggering macho man, both on the ice and off - only adds to the absurdity."Blades of Glory" never aspires to be anything more than a dopey, crowd-pleasing, mainstream comedy, and, as such, it generally hits the mark.  It's true that it runs out of comic steam from time to time and that it is more amusing when the two men are arch rivals  than when they are the best of friends, but there are enough laughs to make the film decent fun for the not-too-critical viewer.  Ferrell and Heder make an enjoyable comic team, while acting stalwart Craig T. Nelson provides just the right balance as their winning-obsessed coach.  As the evil, self-absorbed sister-and-brother duo determined to sabotage the boys' chances, Amy Poehler and Will Arnett, fine comic actors under most other circumstances, are burdened here with having to bring to life two overly broad stereotypes.  Despite their talents, that effort ultimately exceeds their grasp.Special note should be made of the amazing CGI work, without which this film could never have been made.  Even though we know none of these actors could possibly be doing any of these skating moves in real life, we are thoroughly convinced of its verisimilitude for the duration of the film.  And the movie does a nice job lampooning all the snazzy graphics, corny biographical features, and sappy, self-important commentary that have become a staple of modern TV sports programming.

reviewText: A thoroughly enjoyable parade of chuckles (and, sometimes, embarrassing movie theater snorts) from beginning to end, "Blades of Glory" is well worth the price of admission and hour and a half of your time. Will Ferrell has not hid a roadblock yet, continuing in stride with yet another solid showcase for his comedic chops. Jon Heder really clinches it all with his less-is-more approach to comedy and androgynous antics.Ferrell is Chazz Michael Michaels (!) and Heder is Jimmy McElroy, a pair of rival skating stars (or, perhaps in Jimmy's case, starlet) who become banned from professional competition after a short but brutal public fight after both are too proud to share a tie victory. However, an obsessed male fan of Jimmy's informs him a few years later (despite the restraining orders) that he can actually still compete, due to a legal loophole. The hitch? He can only perform with a partner.Before they know it, Jimmy and Chazz are in cahoots to compete together in the first ever male/male skating duo, much to the dismay of the fiercely competitive Waldenbergs, a German brother/sister skating duo portrayed with comic zest by SNL alums Will Arnett and Amy Pohler. Under the direction of Jim's former coach, portrayed by the always enjoyable Craig T. Nelson, the two prepare for a comeback.Along the way, he manages their egos, whips Chazz back into shape, toughens Jimmy up (well, slightly), and teaches them both an important routine he is sure will give them the edge over the competition with the help of Jesse, played by Romany Malco, best known for his portrayal of Jay in the 40-Year-Old Virgin. The Waldenbergs, however, have other plans, including using their pretty, unassuming sister Katie to sabotage the boys by driving a wedge between them. Katie eventually gives in to her desires, taking the moral high road and falling for Jimmy, and her brother and sister to resort to more drastic means of sabotage.All the while, Ferrell and Heder rule as a duo. So much is their chemistry that they will hopefully go on to work together more in the future. The sight of Ferrell in that 70's disco king hairdo is altogether funny enough, but the writing is clever, the premise ripe for great physical comedy, and the actors perfect for their parts.Luke Wilson drops in for a small role as the therapist assigned to help a group of sex addicts (Ferrell's really great here), and a host of celebrities of the world of professional skating are also featured. Nancy Kerrigan in particular provides a laugh as she rejects Chazz's advances. William Daniels, best known as Mr. Feeney on the TV series "Boy Meets World," is also nice to see as he plays a high-ranking skating official intent on foiling the boys' comeback.

reviewText: Will Ferrell has quickly built up one of the most impressive sets of film comedies in recent memory.  A solid anchor in the Ben Stiller-Wilson Brother comedy team, Ferrell has been as memorable as any comedic actor with his over-the-top performances in "Old School," "Anchorman:  The Legend of Ron Burgandy," and "Talladega Nights."  With the success of movies spoofing "sports" such as dodgeball, ping pong, and, yes, NASCAR, it was just a matter of time before male figure skating received its comeuppance."Blades of Glory" has an incredibly promising premise.  Chazz Michael Michaels (Ferrell) and Jimmy MacElroy (Jon Heder, "Napoleon Dynamite") are the two leading male figure skaters in the world.  Where MacElroy is all refinement and unwittingly reeks of homosexuality, Michaels is profane and rampantly heterosexual - the only winner of a gold medal and an Adult Film Award.  Where MacElroy skates to Andrea Bocelli and Sarah Brightman's "Con te partiro," Michaels skates to Billy Squiers' "The Stroke."Fisticuffs result when Michaels and MacElroy tie for a gold medal, with both skaters being banned from the sport.  Both hit rock bottom (MacElroy's fall is particularly funny, ousted by his adopted father) but are given hope when MacElroy's male stalker finds a loophole - the ban does not apply to pairs figure skating.  So under the tutelage of Coach (Craig T. Nelson, natch), Michaels and MacElroy try to regain their fallen glory . . . as a skating pair.There is a lot of worthy skewering of the cliches of figure skating in "Blades," and there are also several  skating sequences that look very realistic thanks to CGI - it looks like Ferrell and Heder did all their own skating, which they absolutely did not.The problem with "Blades" is the absence of a worthy villain.  Sure, there is a villain, in the form of Stranz Van Waldenberg (Will Arnett) and his skating partner/sister Fairchild (Amy Poehler).  These two are the leading pair in figure skating, and they claim to stop at nothing to eliminate the competition.  And yet these two are given remarkably little to do.  One creepy thing they can do is send their mousy sister, Katie (Jenna Fischer, "The Office") to do their dirty work.  This naturally falls apart as Katie falls for MacElroy, but not before Jenna Fischer gets to prove that she is quite the sex-pot despite her cuddly-sweet work on "The Office."The entire plot of "Blades of Glory" seems to be on autopilot, trusting that the comedy will come merely from the scene of having two guys skating together.  The only inspired moment comes when Coach introduces Michaels and MacElroy to skating's most dangerous move, "The Iron Lotus," by watching some North Korean films.  But in general the jokes are rather predictable and the conflict routine.  Will Ferrell is worth watching in anything, and Fischer and Heder give it their all, but all in all you have to put "Blades" in the class of second-tier Ferrell comedies.
summary: Uneven comedy's high points matched by low points; not Ferrell's best comedy

reviewText: Blades of Glory is very much in the same league as Talledega Nights, for viewers familiar with that movie. Again, Ferrell takes a niche sport and lampoons it with hilariously over the top satire. Whereas Talladega Nights took the Red State staple sport of Nascar Racing, Blades of Glory goes the other way and takes the posturing, ego driven, highly camp world of ice dancing. Ferrell teams up with Jon Heder, most known for his cult success in Napoleon Dynamite, and forges an unlikely partnership. A gamble, as they are two very different comic actors, and the result could have been an ugly oil and water separation, but they hit it off. Playing the parts of two rival champion skaters, Ferrell a swarthy man on blades, Heder a delicate swan like soul, they find themselves disqualified from the sport after an altercation. A downward spiral results, until they discover a way back in - in the pairs event. From here the plot is as predictable as 'School of Rock', but that doesn't detract from the laughs. The unlikely duo grapple with intensive training regimes and forge a bond, until a rival skater pair try to sabotage their progress. The action unfolds in a realistic ice scape of dark cabins, Canadian cities and grabs the attention more than Talledega Nights, even if the plot is not quite so nuanced. The climax - the dreaded Iron Lotus - responsible for several beheadings, is the ultimate close shave for the contestants. Will they succeed? Of course you know they will. But there is laughs in the trying. Recommended.

reviewText: Equally absurd and uproariously funny, Blades of Glory never lets up with the comic hijinks and the harebrained mockery of figure skating. Ferrell and Heder play off each other's ridiculous banter and hilarious improvisations to create a uniquely entertaining not-so-family comedy worthy of taking home the gold. Never has senselessness been so much fun.Chazz Michael Michaels is a rowdy, showman rock star on ice who is skating his way to a gold medal. Jimmy MacElroy is an overly feminine figure skater whose signature move is to release a wild dove at the end of his performance. Having been bitter rivals throughout their careers, they break out into a fiery brawl when they tie for gold at the figure skating World Championships, which leaves them permanently banned from figure skating. After several years of obscurity they reunite to exploit a loophole that will allow them to compete in the pairs competition and give them one more shot at the coveted gold. But can they set aside their rivalry and bickering long enough to show the world the most stunning guy-on-guy figure skating stunts ever choreographed?Will Ferrell's brand of comedy isn't for everyone. But for those who admire his bluntly immature and often incredibly childish blend of humor, Blades of Glory will hit the spot. Ferrell gets to play his typical loud-mouthed spontaneous ruffian who dishes out mindless rants at every skeptic remark. While mostly nonsensical, the audience is usually inclined to laugh at every ridiculous thing he spouts. The general personality of his characters essentially never changes, but the supporting actors and settings are what keep his films fresh. In previous Ferrell outings such as Talladega Nights, the pairing of Ferrell and John C. Reilly didn't display nearly enough comedic chemistry, and while Sacha Baron Cohen is individually funny, that combination also didn't garner much zest. In Blades of Glory however, Jon Heder brings a familiar face and a unique style of visual humor to the stage and makes for a much better pairing. Poor Heder will probably never shake the goofy Napoleon Dynamite character he so adroitly perfected, but here it serves him well. Blades of Glory gives audiences who are looking for more than a one-man-show something to fall back on should either character not appear completely appealing. In addition, an excellent supporting cast boosts everyone's performances, and hilarious cameos put Blades of Glory at the top of the Will Ferrell genre.Ferrell is at his obnoxious best, spurting comebacks and grossly immature quips about his various tattoos and uncontrollable sex addiction. Shaggy brown hair and a grungy rock star getup complete his ingenious look. The majority of his comedy feeds off his mangy appearance, and the rest is an inspiring blend of slapstick and gay jokes. Jon Heder likewise is excellent as the prissy MacElroy who gets disowned by his billionaire father (William Fichtner) after 22 years. Heder's role is equally imbecilic, but his character melds with Ferrell in an onscreen chemistry that few comedy duos can achieve. His mop-like blond wig and ambiguous sexuality comprise a large percentage of the physical comedy and back-and-forth raving between the two. Add to that Amy Poehler and Will Arnett who, while a tad generic as the evil rival team, are still incredibly fun to watch. When Arnett's Stranz Van Waldenberg and Chazz engage in a slow-speed pursuit across the souvenir shops at the championship stadium, struggling to run with their blades on, you'll be rolling with laughter at the absurd slapstick. Jenna Fischer (from the American version of The Office) turns in a great performance as the shy and reserved Katie Van Waldenberg who falls for MacElroy's boyish charms. In perhaps the funniest scene in the film, Ferrell crudely coaches Heder on how to ask out the nervous Katie over the phone, who is similarly being guided by the fiendish Poehler. The delirious dialogue in this scene as well as throughout the rest of the film is hilariously scripted and a constant source of laughter.Another inspiring blend of infantile humor, slapstick, and daffy characters, Blades of Glory is one of the funniest films of the year. Sure to do Will Ferrell fans proud, this surprisingly inaccurate figure skating parody matches perfectly with the humorous absurdity of Ferrell's other "classics" Anchorman and Talladega Nights.- Mike Massie

reviewText: Will Ferrell continues his efforts to dominate the small, but apparently lucrative "sports comedy" genre with "Blades of Glory", a comedy about figure skaters, a subject ripe for parody and Ferrell is about the only person so uninhibited to take on such a role, the man will do anything for a laugh. So it would seem to be a match made in heaven. And "Blades" does have some laughs, and it is extremely stupid, but in a good, funny way, so why didn't I laugh more?Chazz Michael Michaels (Ferrell, continuing the tradition of giving his character's ludicrous names, i.e., Ricky Bobby, Ron Burgundy), vies for the gold medal in Men's Figure Skating at the World Passport Games. His main rival, Jimmy MacElroy (Jon Heder), adopted by his dad (William Fichtner) because he stood the best chance of winning a gold medal, is so famous he has a stalker. They tie at the Games and their egos get in the way during the medal ceremony causing the mascot to catch fire. The Skating Federation Committee (chaired by actor William Daniels, but populated with Peggy Fleming, Dorothy Hamill, Nancy Kerrigan and Brian Boitano) immediately ban both from the sport. Three and a half years later, MacElroy's dad has disowned him and Jimmy now works in a sports shop. Michaels is now working in a low budget ice show. MacElroy learns of a loophole; he was banned from Men's Figure Skating, but he can still compete in pairs. Jimmy approaches Michaels at the ice show and they soon convince MacElroy's old coach (Craig T. Nelson) to help them train. The attention they garner makes Stranz and Fairchild Van Waldenberg (real-life husband and wife Will Arnett, TV's "Arrested Development", and Amy Poehler, TV's "Saturday Night Live"), an incestuous brother and sister Pairs Figure Skating team, jealous. They will stop at nothing to remain number one and get another gold medal. They guilt trip their normal sister, Katie (Jenna Fischer, TV's "The Office"), into spying on the new competition.Directed by Josh Gordon and Will Speck and written by a number of writers who have worked on previous films starring Will Ferrell, the film is tailor made as a showcase for Ferrel's talents. And this is part of the problem. Don't get me wrong, "Blades" has some laughs and Ferrell is very funny, he usually is. But Ferrell is, essentially, playing it safe here with a basic variation of the same character he has already played as Ron Burgundy and Ricky Bobby. Chazz Michael Michaels is dumb, a lummox who is amazingly a figure skating champion, and also a sex addict. These are all traits he seems to be channeling from the other characters he has already portrayed. When an actor surrounds themselves with the same writers and same director (or caliber of director) on a consistent basis, and they cater to the star's talents, how is the star ever going to grow and show us his true talents? Or remind us of the brilliance he once showed. This is one of the reasons why "Stranger than Fiction" was so great. Ferrell was working outside of his comfort zone and doing great work. Much more low key work, but great nonetheless. In "Blades of Glory", he plays a safer character almost guaranteeing the film will be a financial success ensuring a steady flow of $20 million paychecks.That said, just the sight of Ferrell, with his less than chiseled body, on figure skates, wearing Lycra costumes, is a funny image. And he plays into the stereotypical perception we have of sports stars, the world is theirs and everyone else is a guest. As his career hits the skids, he becomes a performer in an ice show, guzzling booze while in costume, and has a few funny moments. Later, as he goes to counseling for his sex addiction, the film takes a wrong turn. The idea is funny, but beyond a Sex Addicts Anonymous meeting, nothing funny is really done with it. Also, the film is PG-13 and constant references to sex addiction seem a little out of place for the majority of the audience.Jon Heder is good as Jimmy MacElvoy (and a major improvement from his last role in "School for Scoundrels"). Clearly patterned after skaters like Brian Boitano and Elvis Stoyko, MacElvoy has a shock of platinum blond hair, always perfectly coiffed, and seems most at home when skating and performing a tribute to peacocks. He is completely smitten with Katie and this leads to some sweet moments.As Jimmy and Chazz practice, Jimmy appears to be enjoying some of the hand holds Chazz is using, leading us to question if Jimmy is straight. It seems odd that in a film about figure skating, all of the lead characters are straight and there is never a question about their sexuality. In fact, Chazz seems to have the sexual addiction to erase any possibility that he isn't heterosexual. The same can be said of Will Arnett's character; he almost seems to be interested in his sister to erase any possibility of being gay. But in this case, the incestuous relationship provides an interesting slant and a couple of laughs, pointing out how seriously screwed up they are. Jimmy is a little more ambiguous, but he is clearly interested in Katie and they go on a date. They missed a golden opportunity at satire with this omission. How many times have we seen a flamboyant male figure skater win medals and then the rumors begin swirling? Often, they vehemently deny they are gay. Sometimes, they admit it. If the filmmakers included one gay character, they could have addressed some of these issues. Yes, I know. Not very politically correct, but these films are usually at least a little Un-PC so it seems a bit of a let down when they aren't.Will Arnett and Amy Poehler are more consistently funny as the brother-sister Pairs team who dress up in outrageous outfits, do interpretations of famous events and like to lounge around on bear skin rugs. At one point, we see Arnett's Stranz running around in a suit with rhinestone pinstripes and a Presidential Seal on the back. A few moments later, we see Poehler's Fairchild running around dressed like Marilyn Monroe.Unfortunately, Jenna Fischer just doesn't even register on screen. When an actor is surrounded by people playing broad, over the top characters, they have to work very hard to make a `normal' character seem normal. Fischer plays Katie, the guilt-ridden sister of Stranz and Fairchild. She is supposed to be the normal person of the lot and she is, just way too normal. Anytime she appears on screen, she speaks in her soft, pleasant voice, much like her character, Pam, on "The Office". Because she is surrounded by such insanity, she doesn't even make an impression. It's too bad, because I think she has some talent and could prove a nice romantic comedy lead.William Fichtner, Rob Corddry and others pop up in cameos. Craig T. Nelson plays Coach, their trainer and motivator.The finale is a bit long on antics and short on actual skating. It seems like it would have been more interesting for them to integrate the two a little more completely."Blades of Glory" is a fun movie, but it could've been more or a contender; funnier, raunchier, more madcap than it is. As it plays now, it will probably become the type of film that you will most likely leave on if you run across it playing on cable. You won't search it out, but if it's on, you probably won't turn it off.

reviewText: Movie - 4.5I've always been a fan of Will Ferrell. His juvenile hijinks, potty-mouth humor, and physical mannerisms are something I've come to enjoy over the course of his career, and not even so much during his SNL stint, but from his work in Anchorman on up. Meanwhile, Jon Heder certainly made his mark in comedy with his portrayal of the socially awkward and quirky Napoleon Dynamite, something of a surprising low-budget oddity that probably caught a lot of other people off guard as well. Put these two together in a movie produced by, you guessed it, Ben Stiller, and you've got a very silly and over-the-top sports comedy. Like a certain other Ben Stiller film about the comedic sports underdog story (Dodgeball), Blades of Glory is another mishmash of elements that is meant to, first and foremost, entertain, but also give some kind of weird, outlandish version of inspiration at the same time. Chazz Michael Michaels (Ferrell) and Jimmy MacElroy (Heder) are figure skating's top two stars. Skills-wise, they're the best at what they do, but couldn't be more opposite from one another in terms of personality. Hating each others' guts and being forced to share Olympic gold, they get into a scuffle during the awards ceremony and are banned for life from singles skating. But upon an urging by MacElroy's creepiest and most obsessed fan, Hector (Nick Swardson), a loophole is found in the rules saying MacElroy can still compete in doubles. Predictably, as if you couldn't tell by the cover, MacElroy and Michaels become male doubles skating partners and attempt to achieve gold once again. If you know Will Ferrell's style of comedy and like it, then there's not much else to be said. The film is raunchy, silly, quirky, and not all that high-brow outside of a delightful performance by Jenna Fischer (who looked surprisingly hot in lingerie). Will Arnett and Amy Poehler co-star (with Fischer) as the opposing team, and Craig T. Nelson, as you can guess, plays Ferrell and Heder's coach.Video - 4.5Having watched quite a few different types of genres on BD lately (lots of comedy, but the occasional drama and action flick), I have to say I'm surprised at the level of picture quality presented in a lot of the comedies I've seen, and Blades of Glory looks as glorious as its title implies. The color palette full of blues, whites, and shiny variations of the two, with a splash of red, looks stunning. From the very outset of the opening sequence where the two skaters are competing against one another at the Olympics, there's a very nice sense of pop to the overall picture. The details in their costumes, the clarity of the crowd, and the flawless digital removal of all the wiring looks excellent, which to me is kind of shocking for a simple comedy movie. All the little sequins on Heder's peacock suit, the bright reds and oranges on Ferrell's fire suit, or their outer space and electro-laden lights on their space suits look remarkably clear and vibrant. Outside of competition, blacks and contrast handle especially well revealing shadows, lines, facial features, and overall image detail in a clear, almost lifelike manner. Again, it's all about the costuming. My favorite one outside of the skater suits was Jenna Fischer's lingerie. I thought she was kind of cute on The Office and all, but wow. That black nightie with the all the cleavage and the fishnet stalkings look great. Oh, and so does the quality of black levels within the costume itself. The only downside to the picture? Saturation tends to be a little low on the non-competition scenes reserving a lot of the film's lighting and shine for the glossier parts of the movie, but I never found it to be a huge problem. It does, however, knock the overall transfer down just a bit, but is a beauty to behold, regardless.Audio - 4.5Back in the day before Dolby TrueHD and DTS-HD MA became the economical norm for disc space, there once was a codec called Uncompressed PCM. And while it took up a good deal of memory, it packed a wallop of a bit rate. Blades of Glory, for all its ridiculousness, got a mind-bottling presentation from Paramount/Dreamworks with an audio encode of 6.9Mbps, that's nearly twice the bit rate of Avatar. Strange for a sports comedy to get such royal treatment, I know, when so many other newly re-/released and catalog titles are still getting shafted with lossy Dolby Digital (*cough* Warner Brothers), but big thanks to the people at Paramount for giving Blades a very excellent aural presentation. My biggest surprise upon a few re-watches on my newly-equipped HT setup (new center, fronts, and sub added since then) is the amount of directionality and separation within the film's sound design. Something I've always liked about sports movies is the ambiance of crowd noise, and this track definitely didn't disappoint. Dialogue remains clear and centered, while the front sides and rears do a tremendous job of placing cheers, random fans voicing their support, and camera clicks all over the place. The score by Theodore Shapiro or what few instances there are of record label songs totally immerse you. Aerosmith's I Don't Wanna Miss a Thing and Queen's Flash are two great songs by two very great bands, and hearing them in lossless audio during the competitive events is a blast every time. The only downside, or rather the only elements not truly taken advantage of, are the LFEs. While there is some slight bass from the music, your sub never really gets a workout until the very last scene with some fireworks and Ferrell blasting fire into the camera. But all in all, the sound couldn't be any better.Extras - 3.5There aren't a whole lot of extras, but a good majority of them are in HD and pretty entertaining for what they're worth. There's a making-of, a segment for the skate choreography, one for costuming, various interviews with cast and crew, deleted scenes, alternate takes, and a trailer that amount to a little over an hour in total duration. One of the highlights for me was the making-of, in which Ferrell, Heder, Fischer, Stiller, and the two directors are very candid and seriously funny (as in serious, yet jocular) about how the movie came about, what they hoped to "achieve" by making it, and their experiences in filming it. My second favorite would have to be the interview with Arnett and Poehler, I liked them for what little exposure I had to their SNL days, but I've seen or heard them in a few movies since then and like their chemistry and overall demeanor a lot. Lastly, my favorite extra is the unscripted Moviefone Q&A; between Ferrell, Heder, and Arnett. The three get along very well, don't take the interview too seriously, and offer some pretty funny responses to the questions they get asked. My one disappointment in this package, however, is the lack of a commentary. Had those three taken the time to sit down, or maybe if a combination of them were in the booth with Stiller, Poehler, Nelson, Fischer, Swardson (maybe in-character as Hector) or either of the directors, I think this would've made for a great, great listen to compliment the zaniness of the film itself. It's a darn shame nothing was made, but there's still a good amount of extras here that fans would probably get a kick out of.Overall - 4.5Blades of Glory is crazy and over-the-top. It's a story about male pairs figure skating with raunchy humor, sexual references, a balanced dose of slapstick, and even a little wordplay here and there. As ridiculous as the premise seems, it's also a movie in the care of some really good comedic actors in Ferrell, Heder, Fischer, Arnett, and Poehler, all of who give great deliveries and possess excellent chemistry with one another. With near-reference picture and sound and a slightly underwhelming, but still entertaining, set of extras, Blades of Glory comes highly recommended. Boom!

reviewText: Joking or not, producer Ben Stiller says it was his dream to do a movie about men's figure skating.  While there are some funny moments, Blades of Glory (2007) is only a mildly entertaining farce, that doesn't seem to show the sport of skating a great deal of respect.Bitter rivals Chazz Michael Michaels (Will Ferrell) and Jimmy MacElroy (Jon Heder), are banned for life from competitive skating, after a scandalous incident on the ice.  The pair are relegated to obscure jobs, until they discover a loophole in the regulations, and decide to partner up to make another bid for gold, but this time skating in the pairs event.  Under the guidance of Coach (Craig T. Nelson) and choreographer Jesse (Romany Malco) the partners train and practice, attempting to execute the dangerous "iron lotus" maneuver.  Their major competition are Stranz Van Waldenberg (Will Arnett) and his sister Fairchild (Amy Poehler), "who burst out of the womb and on to the ice".  Younger sister Katie (Jenna Fischer), rounds out team Van Waldenberg.In a sport known for grace and elegance, the teaming of two men presents some broad comedic possibilities, and the film mostly goes for unsubtle options.  An example being, when the two men slam their crotches together, in the finale of a routine.  The skating is fairly well executed, although the amount of skating featured in the film is rather limited, and usually performed at very slow speeds.  Give the actors some credit for getting on the ice, and editing helps give the impression that you are seeing more skating skill than is actually present.  Some of the skating outfits are cool, while others are tacky and outrageously bad.The Van Waldenberg's resort to kidnapping to try and prevent the inevitable showdown, but Chazz and Jimmy manage to overcome the obstacles and make it to the arena just in time.  Dressed in costumes inspired by the movie Tron, they execute the famed iron lotus maneuver, and fly off as skating legends.Although he does overplay his role as a preening, showoff, Will Ferrell surprisingly remains pretty well under control.  The provocative male/male partnership mostly avoids controversy, and follows very conventional lines with the shy Jimmy pursuing a romance with the repressed Katie.  There is no love for confessed "sex-addict" Chazz, although he does get a huge handful of Katie's breasts.  A bit more daring are the hints of incest between Stranz and Fairchild, but nothing really inflammatory occurs to risk the PG-13 rating.The presence of the real life skating commentators, Scott Hamilton and Jim Lampley, adds some credibility, realism, and humor to the proceedings, as Hamilton in particular, hams it up big time.  Former skating champions Dorothy Hamill, Peggy Flemming, Brian Boitano, and Nancy Kerrigan flash by in cameo roles.The DVD has some decent extras that are mostly fluff, but no commentary track.  Of interest are the deleted scenes, which provide more details of the backstory between Chaz and Jimmy.  The acting performances are mostly in synch with the style of comedy.  Jenna Fischer is very good, although it would have been nice to see more of Amy Poehler's talents.  Will Ferrell may be a little subdued here, but his performance probably won't disappoint his fans.

reviewText: Like real life, in BLADES OF GLORY, the top of the realm of figure skating is winning gold at the international games (the name of the organization evades me, but it is a parody of the Olympics). The two top men's figure skaters in the world are two Americans who are polar opposites of each other. His arch rival and polar opposite is Chazz Michael Michaels (Will Ferrell), a partying, booze-loving, sex addict who has brought a new fan and market base to the world of figure skating (think of what Happy Gilmore did to the world of golf in HAPPY GILMORE and you get the idea). MacElroy performs an amazing number at the championships, but Michaels is able to match his performance and the rivals end up sharing the gold medal. A fist fight between the two breaks out on the medal podium and a hearing is held. The committee is quite harsh and instead of suspensions, takes their medals away and bans them from competing in men's single competition. MacElroy's dad abandons him and Michaels turns to booze.Fast forward four years later and MacElroy's stalker informs him that there's a loophole in the committee's decision. He's been banned from singles competition, but not pairs. MacElroy seeks out his former Coach (Craig T. Nelson) and informs him of the loophole. Initially, Coach thinks the idea is insane, but becomes convinced they can make history if they can get Chazz Michael Michaels to join the team and form the first all-male pairs team in the history of figure skating. Michaels is initially reluctant, but then agrees. The duo can perform moves never seen before because of their combined strength. However, the reigning champions, incestuous brother and sister Stranz (Will Arnett) and Fairchild Van Waldenberg (Amy Poehler) don't take kindly to the new duo and use everything and everyone at their disposal, including their younger sister Katie (Jenna Fischer) to bring team MacElory and Michaels down.There was a lot of potential for BLADES OF GLORY to be a hilarious comedy. The movie does have some funny scenes, but it never reaches the level of humor such as TALLADEGA KNIGHTS or ANCHORMAN did. The part of Chazz Michael Michaels was written for Ben Stiller, but Stiller turned the part down apparently because he thought it was too similar to other comedies he has done. Ferrell stepped in and does a good job but he displays no new tricks. Besides, his character is only one character in the plot. Jon Heder does a good job of portraying MacElroy. Heder serves as a great foil to Ferrell and I was glad to see him on screen and holding ground against the great comic. Jenna Fischer is also excellent and the innocence she exudes as the youngest Van Waldenberg is perfectly matched with Heder's sweet, but goofy MacElroy. Will Arnett and Amy Poehler also do a good job of portraying the evil Van Waldenberg siblings, darlings of the figure skating world.I think the problem with BLADES OF GLORY lies in the writing. The writing team responsible for the script has worked with Ferrell before which could have been a huge asset. Instead, it turns into a liability because instead of giving Ferrell better material, they just use the same gags that they've used before, e.g. this is the part that Ferrell gets drunk, this is the part where Ferrell takes off most of his clothes and the audience laughs at his normal average-looking body, this is the bit where Ferrell makes an awkward sexual advance. The movie would have been funnier if Ferrell had been able to do something new.In addition, the pacing of the movie is a bit off. The film doesn't really feel like a film and instead feels like a made-for-tv movie. I think if the writers (and director for that matter) had taken a little more time for character development, e.g. as how MacElroy and Michaels change from being worst enemies into the best of friends or the budding romance between MacElroy and Katie Van Waldenberg, then the film would have been more humorous and enjoyable.Lastly, I don't think the writers and filmmakers did enough research into the world of figure skating. Some of the events of the film don't make any sense (the lifetime ban for fighting is ludicrous, especially sense the film offers no precedent for it). BLADES OF GLORY seems to be a movie that is supposed to be a parody of the world of figure skating. Instead it ends up being just a caricature instead of a parody. Had more research gone into writing the script, the film would have been stronger and funnier. After all, the world of figure skating is ripe for a roll-on-the-floor-with-laughter comedy that parodies the sport. BLADES OF GLORY wanted to be that picture, but it didn't quite make the cut.In short, though there are some funny scenes in BLADES OF GLORY and solid performances from the cast, the movie comes off being better than an extended SNL skit, but not as good as it should have been. I'd recommend this movie for fans of any of the major actors (Ferrell, Heder, Arnett, Fischer, etc.). However, if you want to watch a gut-busting funny movie, you're better off watching TALLADEGA NIGHTS or THE ANCHORMAN.

reviewText: Will Ferrell springboards off the success of Talladega Nights and lampoons another niche sport in Blades of Glory, a satire of figure skating.  Although his character is more akin to his self absorbed and perverse Ron Burgundy, the film relies on the same formula that succeeded in his Nascar film, as joke after joke is leveled at the sport most of us don`t quite "get".  The plot is full of one movie cliché after another, everything from a romance ruined when one party misinterprets a precarious situation to a breakneck chase to reach the arena in time to compete, but as long as you understand going in what to expect, this is a solid Will Ferrell film.
